title: Beginner/Intermediate studio setup and camera setup (my personal preference)
subtitle: Theory of Photography. I'd like to take a moment today to give out a brief list of items on which you can spend your money, to have a minimal studio, and a camera setup (my personal, biased preference) with which you can take on quite a number of photography tasks and subjects.
descr:
What I have not looked much into is portable strobe lighting (what people would call `flash`). It is non-trivial, and immensely useful, to be able to use flash to photograph subjects such as people - and not have to carry a whole studio with you. So, other people will give you better advice than I can, on how to do this. I historically shoot mostly without flash, so I do my hardware selection based on this preference.

I also have a strong preference to rangefinders over SLRs (single lens reflect, a type of camera. The digital SLRs are called DSLRs). With that in mind... here is my camera setup:

X-E1 with 18mm lens.



Purchased separately in 2013 (from Ebay or Amazon), they will run you up about $1700 including tax. I strongly recommend purchasing warranty also (from square trade), to give you a peace of mind. You don't want to be running around with a hugely expensive camera and worry about it all the time. Worry about the quality of your pictures instead! Be free!

It may not look so, but a prime fast wide lens is the single most useful lens you can have. Prime means, no zoom. Fast means, large aperture opening (f/2 on this 18mm), which means you can shoot in the dark with no flash. And a rangefinder as opposed to a DSLR means that the cameara is light and compact - with still all the professional features that you expect from a DSLR. In fact, the designers at Fuji have done a great job in terms of usability, so I am happy to say that the X-E1 is well-designed! It gives you a variety of color options (film simulation), three different aspect ratios (try shooting square aspect ratio - it's great for portraits), full HD video, old-school controls that are fast and intuitive to use, 6 frames per second continuous shooting...

The only disadvantage to the camera that I can think of is, it focuses rather poorly. And it is not designed to be manually focused (although you can, it is not the simplest/fastest thing in the world). So you will have to always be mindful of your focusing, while shooting. I find this to be an acceptable trade-off for the camera. I love the small size of X-E1, and I am careful about focus so I'm okay with the slow-inaccurate autofocus, I know how to use it.

That's it! On to basic lighting equipment. I wrote in the title basic / intermediate, and that is correct. A photographer who knows what he is doing will take advantage of the same setup as the beginner setup, and have great success with it. So let's get to it.

The single most important piece of lighting equipment you can get is a 5-in-1 reflector. I got me something like this: http://www.amazon.com/Fotodiox-Premium-Grade-Professional-Collapsible-Reflector/dp/B003Y2KC7W/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1380078397&sr=8-2&keywords=5+in+1+reflector


You will need an assistant to use it, but it is great. It is mobile, requires no batteries, and it can either remove shadow, add shadow, remove highlight, or add highlight - a very versatile thing when shooting portraits, even on the go!

Next, you need a backdrop. The backdrop itself, and a stand for it. In 2013, that may run you up about $80.

Next, you will need strobe lights! That's about $300 and well worth it if you are going to be doing portraits. A 750W setup is good enough: http://www.amazon.com/Professional-Photographic-Studio-Strobe-Flash/dp/B003LYURRI/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1380079158&sr=8-2&keywords=strobe+lights+750w+photography You need three lights really: one primary for the face, one modifying for the face (to make the shadows less), and one for the background. Or, two lights for the face and one for backlight. Three lights turn out to be very useful. You need more than 2, and if you get 4 you may not use the 4th very often, so 3 is a good number to get.



That's it! The most expensive thing is the camera and the lens. I strongly recommend sticking to prime lenses. Having the ability to zoom will actually distract you from taking good pictures. Next, a $50 reflector is the best use of $50, and if you have about $300 of 2013 money, you can start building your studio by purchasing a set of three strobe lights. Oh, make sure that your set comes in its own bag, which is extremely useful. Then, you can get a $80 background but you really don't have to - just be creative with your backgrounds. But if you have come this far, you'll probably end up with a background. And lastly - enjoy taking photos, and photograph every day! ^__^

Related gallery: http://piousbox.com/en/galleries/show/2013-photo-equipment/0

title: Not all things are forgiven
subtitle: Not all relationships can be salvaged after infidelity.
descr: Not all relationships can be salvaged after infidelity. It seems in our society that a lot of couples tend to “work things out” and move on, forget what had happened and start a fresh page. Not always. Sometimes sleeping with someone other than your gf/bf is the end no matter how much you try to tell yourself that you can get over the fact or try to think of the happy days you experienced. A friend of mine opened up recently about how his wife of 10 years had an affair. Women are just as guilty. The true answer is why “cheating” when you know the consequences? Her excuse was that she lacked attention from her then husband, who worked two jobs to support his family and put his daughter through college. Than tell me, what is the urge for betrayal knowing all of that could be lost and the family split? If you were truly unhappy why not speak, talk, tell him how you feel and what you lack, what you desire, tell him the truth. Sleeping with another person will not solve problems in your current relationship; it will not form a stronger bond and bring you closer together. It will either drive you far away from each other or teach you to forever doubt the other person. As my friend started to sense his wife’s infidelity perhaps her conscious began to speak. He heard her conversation, read her text messages, and even saw pictures that were not meant for anyone else but her husband, being shared between the two. One night, after her escapade with the non-husband my friend asked her if she wanted to hear a tape he had recently come across which was a phone conversation between her and the other man. She realized what was happening and after an hour of silence came up to her husband and confessed of having an affair. Two kids, 10 years of a relationship, fights, happy days, wild sex, cuddling nights, crying together, experiencing any and every possible emotion that the world can bring and challenge a human being vanquished. The true question is why. Lack of attention is not a reason. It is important to realize that after the line of infidelity has been crossed it may not work out between you and your spouse/bf/gf. Things may not be the same, ever. Will you tell them that you love them? Love is not everything anymore; love is a component of a relationship, there are other factors that play a role such as trust, appreciation, respect. All of those are lost after unfaithfulness. Is it worth it? Was it worth it? My friend tried to stay with his wife, but the pain could not be overcome by him nor perhaps any other man (or woman). When it comes to infidelity it is crucial to realize that your actions may be the end of the relationship. The relationship that you have put time and energy into, the relationship that also involved another human being and their feelings, that even though you will be the one committing the action, the consequences will be felt by your significant other as well. Realize that after one is unfaithful it may not work out any more. Your partner may try to move on and forget of what you did, but it will not be the same. Not all people are capable of forgetting how they’ve been hurt by the person that they believed were purely there for them.

title: An unlikely visitor
descr: My first visit. It takes four and a half hours to drive from Chicago to Pinckneyville. I woke up at 6am and decided not to shower, not eat breakfast just a cup of coffee and straight to my car. I was eager to visit and actually see him face to face rather than a phone conversation like it has been for the past five months. I had no expectations for the people working at the prison, people living around the area or him. I drove and drove, speeding wanting to get there as quickly as I could. Indeed it took me exactly four hrs and thirty some minutes to reach the exit that I needed to take. And I did, it was approximately another 30 miles to the prison. I drove slowly absorbing every little thing the town had to offer, and it wasn’t much. Everything looked empty; houses were half a mile apart from each other if not more. There were no people walking around, cars were broken, the small stores available were shut down already. Every house had a chair or a bench in the front porch, as it was the only source of human interaction in the whole place, if anyone ever sat in those chairs to begin with. Continuing down the road I saw the prison. It looked exactly like a typical prison you would see in a movie. My lack of expectation for the prison was reinforced. I parked my car and was quickly informed that this “was not visitors parking” even though the whole parking lot was empty. So, I re parked my car, left everything besides my ID and $20 and headed towards the building, quickly. There was nobody outside, perhaps because it was cold out, or maybe they never get to go outside. I walked in and was quickly greeted with a dirty look by the correctional officer. I waited and waited and then waited some more, sitting there thinking of how strange it would be to live here, in the middle of nowhere, and what? Work at a prison? Do people know that there are better places out there, more interesting cities or is this ‘okay’ and I’m a stuck up city girl? Who knows but as eager as I was to get there, I was more anxious to leave. Patted down, half undressed and every cavity checked I was escorted to the visiting room. More of a high school type lunch room with octagonal tables bolted down to the floor and four benches attached to it and lots of vending machines (where my $20 came in handy), later found out were mostly empty. I was told where to sit and how to behave. I sat there and waited some more, I was bored and perhaps getting a little nauseous. I saw him come out and walk to check in with the guard and wanted to get up and leave. There he was, in navy blue uniform pants, and a light blue collar shirt with a name tag that said INMATE. It was repulsive and I wanted to disappear from there more than anything else. We hugged, and sat down… since then I have went back to that place more than four times, more than anyone should ever.

title: Travelling on the budget: hostel v hotel. Which is better?
subtitle: Where to stay in a big city, any city - a hostel or a hotel?
descr:
If you are under 35, and you are traveling to a relatively well-known city, a relatively large city, chances are there will be a bunch of hostels available. Hostels are different from hotels in several important ways. You do not get so much privacy, so if you are traveling with your significant other, perhaps it is not the best option ever. Although, there are hostels that provide private rooms and private doubles, perfect for couples.

Cleanliness is also not going to be world-class. On average, a hostel is dirtier than a hotel. That is offset, however, by the price. A hostel is almost always cheaper than the hotel, so if you are traveling on the budget, it may be just the thing.

Some people have a certain prejudice against hostels in that they think hostels are not safe. In my experience, although there can be plenty of thefts (why are you traveling with expensive shit and why are you not watching your shit?), overall hostels are pretty safe. Most of them provide lockers so you can put your laptop/passport in there, and you can use the backpack as your pillow, and when you travel you should be experienced in taking care of your stuff. That said, everything else regarding safety is good. There are no fights and no assaults - a hostel is just another place to stay, on the budget.

The best part of staying in the hostel, however, is when it comes to nightlife and drinking/entertainment. You can meet a lot, no really, a lot of people in hostels. And everybody party. In fact, a lot of hostels are undesireable for me and for a lot of other travelers if the hostel is clean but not much social interaction going on. I personally tend to avoid such places - they are just like hotels for me, kind of boring. And I travel really light, so there isn't much to steal from me.

So overall if you have never considered staying at a hotel, I suggest giving it a try. The best hostel site in USA is perhaps hostelworld.com, though it is by no means complete or the cheapest. But it will take care of 95% of your hostel needs.

That about sums up my opinion on hostels vs hotels. Stay safe, and travel more!

title: What gear should I have riding in the city
subtitle: An intermediate rider explains his gear set for daily riding in the city.
descr:
My current residence is San Francsico (which means that I don't have to worry about snow, black ice, or starting a bike in dead cold) and I have been riding since 2009. Here, the helmet is not optional, it is legally required. Other gear -- well, I have seen and hear more than one opinion on what gear is necessary and what gear is silly/excessive, and I would like to share my own. The boil-down description of my gear set is: as much as possible that you can be comfortable with. There are some tricks, however, read more to discover ;-)

To begin: the helmet. Very important, you probably don't need the most expensive one, but you should also not get the cheapest. Full-face helmet it should be. It should fit SNUGLY, which is important for safety. If you jerk your head left and right the helmet should not move much on the head. This guarantees that upon impact your head will not be bouncing inside the helmet, causing damage to your precious brain/skull.

[pic]

Next: and here is the trick number one. Security camera. The cops are infinitely more respectful if there is a camera pointed at them. I have this Contour Roam, which I highly recommend. It mounts well, gives good quality, and is waterproof (yeah I took it to a mountain waterfall, it really is waterproof). Besides, when you get pulled over, at least you will have some evidence for the court and maybe an interesting video to put on youtube, you never know.

[pic]

Next: Jacket. I have this one from Sedici. Waterproof, ventilated, with winter layer. It is a bit too hot in California on a sunny day, however I pulled all-nighters in it very very comfortably and I think it is worth it to carry it around (the weight!) and sweat in it. I used to debate: jacket or no jacket? The debate have been solved, and I wear jacket at all times regardless of trip duration or destination. Going clubbing, I put the jacket in coat check ($3). And if I must sweat in it, it is still okay because I know that if I have to ride home at 2am in pouring rain, I will actually be okay.

[pic]

Next: these waterproof pants ($20) are largely not used, however if I am riding out in pouring rain, I put these on over jeans or whatever. So I use them very very rarely but I think it is a good idea to have them.

[pic]

Next: And here is the trick number two: knee caps from a dirt setup. You can wear them under your jeans/pants. The way I ride I am not always most careful, and I don't want to have knee surgery if I fall. And also I don't want to wear horribly hot racing pants. Regular pants with these knee protectors do the trick.

[pic]

Next: Boots. Here is a picture of a scar I got from riding.

[pic]

You can see it is above the boot line... I was not wearing the boots when I got the scar, maybe they would help, maybe not. But, after getting this scar, I always wear boots when I ride. These boots are pretty cheap and my advice is that on other than first pair, do not spend less than $100 on boots.

[pic]

gloves. This is pretty standard.

[pic]

I bought a cellphone holder for the gas tank. I use it when I must be checking the GPS.

[pic]

tire pressuge gauge. Check your tires once a month. Correct pressume means better gas mileage and fewer tire replacements, which saves money and inconvenience.

That is all, folks!

title: Three Spiders
subtitle: This is a story about little things.
descr:
Once I was living in Ann Arbor, MI in a shared house and there in the shower there was a spider hanging out, in the corner of the ceiling and two walls. I figure, the moisture in the air has enough appeal to him that he would stay there, and if you look from that corner outwards, there is not much motivation to go anywhere because hey, the walls are the same, so going anywhere, moving your limbs, is just spending energy unnecessarily, yes?
 
So he would just hang out there (oh, it was winter time) and I would look at him every time I take a shower, like whatever. Then a few months later there was another spider next to the first one, I guess they had the same logic/instincts driving them when they took whatever path through the house to end up in that particular spot, on the ceiling of the shower. And with that second spider there I notice how much skinnier the first one is. They are probably the same species and the first one was thin thin thin, perhaps it was already dead by then, whereas the second spider was healthy-looking. So for the next days and days I would look at them two spider there - and the second spider as well as the first one had no reason to go anywhere else, they just spent all the time in that corner, on the ceiling - and as I looked at them I thought, well the second spider is going to starve and die just as the first.
 
Years later, in San Francisco Bay Area I am living in a house and I notice a spider in the ceiling corner of the bathroom there, and I am thinking - okay he is there, the environment is non-threatening, but if he does not move away he is going to die, yes? I want to check if he is still alive so I blow air on him to see if his limbs move more than the flow of air would cause. And the spider does move, he shakes his legs in what appeared to me as a sign of displeasure.
 
Every time I used the bathroom I would blow air on the spider or agitate him in some way to remind him that he is still alive, to remind him of the flow of time, and of that he does not have to be there forever.
 
Then one day I see the spider more or less on his feet, not walking around but at least he is standing in a pose that would let him use this limb strength for motion. It's a bit hard to explain... It is as if when the spider is resting, he is laying down, his legs are not bearing weight. When he stands up, his legs are bearing weight and it is more stressful, more energy consuming, but he is ready for motion.
 
And a few days later the spider was gone. I don't know what happened, maybe he fell and was squashed by one of the other tenants, but I like to think that he became sufficiently aware that staying in that bathroom corner is a slow hunger death, and he left.

title: Chicago: Winding Up in the Windy City
subtitle: When you hear the phrase ‘NBA’s Bulls’, ‘Murderesses Roxie Hart and Velma Kelly’, ‘Illinois’s most populated city”, or ‘windy city’, isn’t it that all you can think of is Chicago? And instead of just thinking about Chicago, why don’t you just pack up and get your feet land into this world-class city?
descr:
When you hear the phrase ‘NBA’s Bulls’, ‘Murderesses Roxie Hart and Velma Kelly’, ‘Illinois’s most populated city”, or ‘windy city’, isn’t it that all you can think of is Chicago? And instead of just thinking about Chicago, why don’t you just pack up and get your feet land into this world-class city?

Here’s the deal: You get to experience an American life of endless possibilities in Chicago while I take care of your bucket list and compass, fair?

Transportation

Well, unless you have wings, knowing how to get there and around the area is a must. You can arrive directly at Chicago via air trip at O’Hare International Airport, which is one of the largest airports in the world, and Midway International Airport, which is located 10 miles from Chicago’s downtown. Also, Go Airport Express and the Van Galder Bus offer airport transfers to and from your hotel.

If you prefer riding through rails or trains, you have a choice between Metra Commuter Rail and Amtrak. It will be cheaper and more convenient to go around Chicago through the Metra as it is the sister company of Chicago Transit Authority and the single journey ticket only costs as low as $2.75 to as high as  $9.25.

If you have a bigger budget for a more convenient and flexible Chicago exploration, then you may choose to hire rent-a-car services from Alamo, Avis, National, Hertz, Enterprise, Dollar, or Budget. Still, another convenient yet more expensive alternative transportation is taking a cab.

Chicago’s Finest

Visit and appreciate Chicago’s museums, Broadways, and gigs which are steeped in the American spirit. First in line of the must-see places is the Art of Institute of Chicago. It is the second-largest museum in the United States exhibiting more than 300,000 artworks which includes Grant Wood’s famous American Gothic. The next museums you should visit are The Field Museum and Museum Campus, Chicago Cubs, and Museum of Science and Industry.

Another to-do item in the bucket list is to watch the hottest shows and gigs in Chicago. Get electrified and be entertained in Broadway in Chicago, Buddy Guy’s Legends, and The Second City.

Chicago’s Highlights

Chicago will not fail to boast its city’s work-of-God landscape. Prepare your copper tone and bikinis for a dip at the Chicago Public Beaches where you can also play volleyball, jog, and picnic while being kissed by the sun. The beaches are always open for everyone in Chicago including the tourists for free.

Another popular destination is the Navy Pier which is known for an outdoor adventure. This is definitely exciting for family and friends as you altogether ride the Ferris wheel, dine on a cruise ship, and jam with the live performance at the open-air Skyline stage. You can also roam around the boardwalk to see the restaurants and souvenir shops.

In case you want to see the entire Chicago at one glance, John Hancock Observatory shall be your interactive telescope. You will see the best of the best bird’s-eye views Chicago has to offer while sipping your cocktail at an altitude of 100 feet above the ground. You get to see all that you have to see without flexing your foot muscles plus you get to save from buying individual tickets.

I have done my part, now it’s your turn to enjoy Chicago with everything planned in the bucket list!

title: Five Things You Should Know Before Flying to Beijing
subtitle: You do not want to go to your dream Beijing escapade with an empty hand. All you need to know is the 5 things that will make your trip remarkable.
descr:
1.    No Visa, No Entry Policy

Without an authenticated visa issued by the People’s Republic of China Embassy, you will have to fly back to your country once you landed in Beijing Capital International Airport. In fact, your Immigration will very unlikely to allow you to board the plane.

However, because China has diplomatic affairs with certain nations, ordinary passport holders who are not endorsed for public affairs from countries such as Brunei, Japan, and Singapore are entitled to 15 days or less visa-free entry and 90 days or less for the citizens of San Marino.

Try your best to get a visa that is good for your entire trip or stay in China because extension requirements are very demanding. You have to open a bank account in China and deposit an amount with a ratio of $100 per one day extension that must reflect in a bank certificate that you must submit to their Public Security Bureau.

2.    Learn Some Basic Chinese

Mandarin is the adopted national language of China. However, Mandarin is also just a dialect and there are so many dialects in China so do not be surprised in case some Chinese will not understand your Mandarin.

You will not survive in Beijing if you do not know some basic Chinese words because most of their citizens barely understand even the simplest and most common English terms.

Here are a few. Take note that merely saying these words are not enough for Chinese people to understand you, you must say them with the proper accent.

Greetings

Hello!                                                   ni hao

How are you?                                     ni hao ma

I can speak a little Chinese.                wo hui shuo yi dian zhong wen

Asking the Way

How can I get to…                              wo zen me neng dao

Where is…                                          zai na er

Thank you!                                          xie xie

Restaurant

May I have this… and that…?                        wo yao dian zhe ge… he na ge…

Don’t make it too spicy, please                       qing bu yao tai la

Can I have… (Please bring me…)?               qing gei wo…

3.    Money Matters

No one goes outside his or her homeland without a pocket money. However, make sure that your pocket money is in US dollars because it is an internationally accepted currency that you can easily convert to any country’s currency. You may have your dollars changed to China Yuan (CNY) at the airport but to be 100% prepared, you must at least have few Yuan with you before going to Beijing.

Market prices in Beijing are affordable and it is highly recommended that you carry smaller denominations of bills and even coins when paying for transportation most especially. You can have one-way trip bus ride for as low as CNY1 (fare varies depending on the distance) and a rice meal for CNY 10. Also, a night in hotels like Home Inn Hotel will only cost you CNY 120 for a night.

4.    Make An Itinerary

Do not wait until you land to the Beijing Capital International Airport before you get a map, buy yourself one and plan your trip day per day so you can get the most out of your trip. Beijing is the cultural capital of China so you must think of the shopping places, museums, parks, and historical sites that you wanted to visit. After that, get the address written both in pinyin and Chinese characters so you may just show it to the driver in case of misunderstanding due to language barriers. Moreover, educate yourself on what transportation means will get you there. Practicality dictates that you avoid riding taxi and take the bus and subway instead.

5.    The Don’ts

Though traveling is pleasurable, you are still not in your comfort zone so better be safe than sorry.  The golden rule is that do not do something you are not sure of.  Do not be discourages because there are only few things you should remember that you should not do.

First, do not ride unlicensed rent-for-a-cars as substitute for taxis, it is prohibited in China and the security in Beijing is really strict.

Second, do not bury your chopsticks on your rice bowl upside down.

Third, do not bring too light and thin clothes because it is normally windy and cold in Beijing.

Fourth, do not forget to bring your passport always with you.

Lastly, do not get drunk and wild. There is a kidney scare in Beijing and most victims are usually drunk vulnerable persons.

 

Make the most out of your trip and enjoy!

title: A Summer To Remember in San Francisco
subtitle: Your Travel Guide to San Francisco
descr:
♫For those who come to San Francisco, Summertime will be a love-in there ♪ Who would forget this piece of advise from the soundtrack song entitled San Francisco (Be Sure to Wear Some Flowers in Your Hair) of the American epic movie Forrest Gump? Let us see the truth behind the message of the song by exploring what San Francisco can offer during the summer season.

Every American would tell you that San Francisco is known as the City by the Bay or the Baghdad by the Bay. And as the only consolidated city-county in California, San Francisco prides itself as Northern California's leading financial  and cultural center. By just looking at the arts and culture events in San Francisco travel, you would be needing at least 49 hours to experience and to see all the featured events varying from theater, film, museums, music,  galleries, festivals, and many more.

2013 Community Festivals to Remember

Nothing beats being culturally immersed in the San Francisco community. Starting this summer you can be part of the historic event called 15th Annual  Bay Area Dance Week around the  East Bay, North Bay, and  South Bay for free. You will be overwhelmed with over 600 free dance events that you can witness. The weeklong celebration will end on May 5 at the Anna Halprin’s Planetary Dance.

Another highlight of the season is the Reasons to be Pretty comedy production by the San Francisco Playhouse. The shows run until May 11 with the last show at 8pm. The ticket prices range from $30 to $70. Very affordable for a live event that will tickle your funny bone, isn’t it?

Nights to Remember

Who says a tourist sleeps at night? Definitely not me. I will even tell you to make the most out of your San Francisco trip by gracing the captivating night sceneries and gatherings.

If you want a nightlife in which you can mix pleasure, socials, cocktails, and biodiversity, the California Academy of Sciences will surely transport you to the underworld minus the scuba diving suit and goggles. And wait, there’s more, get hyped up with the live band or DJ that will make you go salsa as you explore the aquatic exhibits. Take note that this is only open every Thursday from six to ten in the evening (of course!). Dive into this nightlife experience for just a wet and wild ticket price of $12.

And for your thirsty nights, thou shall not miss Southern Pacific Brewing on the list. It is a brewpub with the Southern Pacific railroad theme that will stir your taste well as you chill and chat with your friends and family. Also, it pays to visit  Comstock Salon, The Hidden Vine, Anchor Distilling Company, and Mission Bowling Club.

Landmarks to Remember

A good company of people. Breath taking sceneries. A carefree summer in San Francisco. All you need is a high megapixel camera and your dream picture of paradise is complete!

Despite of its highly industrialized landscape and economy, San Francisco will still amaze you with its marvelous architectures and landmarks such as the famous federal penitentiary Alcatraz, Cable Cars tramway, the Bay Bridge connects San Francisco to Oakland, the Coit Tower on  the Telegraph Hill, the famous shopping place Ferry Building, the “Summer of Love” icon Haight-Ashbury, Alamos Square’s famous Painted Ladies, and a Greek-style Palace of Fine Arts. More important is the Golden Gate Bridge which is hailed as one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World.

And the song never gets old… ♪ for those who come to San Francisco… And be sure to wear some flowers in your hair ♫

title: Health Considerations While Traveling
subtitle: a heads up to prospective travelers
descr:
When you start traveling you put your body in stress, whether you can physically feel it or not. And it does not really matter where you are traveling to, 1st world (Europe to America) or 3rd world (America to America). The fact that you are switching to a new, unpredictable diet and switching away from the normal routine will stress your body quite some ways. It is not bad, it certainly does not mean that you will get sick, however it is something to keep in mind when traveling.

I met a girl in San Francisco and she was complaining how ever since she left Switzerland she has to put a lot of eye drops in her eyes, and cannot use her contacts. Something about the air here in San Francisco that makes her eyes very irritated. She is not sick, but she is certainly inconvenienced, and I think her immune system is working hard to keep her okay.

Another friend of mine, when we were in Rio, after about a month he complained that his joints are all sore, that he sometimes fall asleep because of the pain. He sleeps with a pillow between his knees, and his joints are sore almost all the time. For no particular reason. It went away when he came back to Vancouver.

Myself, I had a few minor things as well while traveling. In Sao Paulo I had my first experience with Conjuntivite, and in Natal, with atheletes foot. Both cured without complications.

Overall, it should be noted by prospective travelers that, even if you are completely healthy and adhere to a good diet and exercise, when you travel you put a lot of stress on your body, and it is quite quite common to experience small health issues and inconveniences. Be ready for it if it does happen. Don't forget to eat and sleep when you travel! Drink plenty of liquids, and be careful with your body when you travel, and in general.

title: Welcome to Chicago
subtitle: Chicago is a huge vibrant city and sprawling metropolitian area. It is the home of the blues and the truth of jazz, the heart of comedy and the first builder of the skyscraper. Here, the age of railroads found its center, and airplanes followed suit. Butcher of hogs and believer in progress, it is one of the world's great cities, and yet the metropolitan luxuries of theater, shopping, and fine dining have barely put a dent in real Midwestern friendliness. It's a city with a swagger, but without the surliness or even the fake smiles that can be found in other cities.
descr:
As the hub of the Midwest, Chicago is easy to find —its picturesque skyline calls across the waters of huge Lake Michigan, a first impression that soon reveals world-class museums of art and science, miles of sandy beaches, huge parks and public art, and perhaps the finest downtown collection of architecture in the world.

With a wealth of iconic sights and neighborhoods to explore, there's enough to fill a visit of weeks or even months without ever seeing the end. Prepare to cover a lot of ground: the meaning of Chicago is only found in movement, through its subways and archaic elevated tracks, in the pride of tired feet and eyes raised once more to the sky.

Many visitors never make it past the attractions in Chicago's large downtown area, but there are also many attractions to be found in the city's other districts. The city consists of three large Sides (the North Side, the South Side, and the West Side) each named according to its direction from the central business district, or the Loop as it is called. Citizens tend to identify strongly with their neighborhood within the city, reflecting real differences in culture and place. Rivalries between the North and South Sides sometimes run deep, while people from the West Side are usually free agents in critical issues like baseball loyalty.

Chicago was known as a fine place to find a wild onion if you were a member of the Potawatomi tribe, who lived in this area of Illinois before European settlers arrived. It was mostly swamps, prairie and mud long past the establishment of Fort Dearborn in 1803 and incorporation as a town in 1833. It could be argued that nature never intended for there to be a city here; brutal winters aside, it took civil engineering projects of unprecedented scale to establish working sewers, reverse the flow of the river to keep it out of the city's drinking supply, and stop buildings from sinking back into the swamps — and that was just the first few decades.

As far as Chicago's weather goes, well let's just say that Chicago is a huge city so things tend to get much more analyzed here than they would in other locales, that includes the weather. No, Chicago doesn't have weather like Honolulu - then again, what other city does? The winters in Chicago are indeed cold, but then again, so is most of the United States from Maine to Utah, with the exception of the extreme southern U.S. In fact, Chicago receives less precipitation (snow and rain) in the winter than East Coast cities like New York City or Boston receive. Chicago's summers are not much hotter than the East Coast, and definitely not as hot as the southern U.S. where there is a nonstop heatwave throughout the summer. There is a good time to be had in any season in Chicago, and the summer offers an array of parades, festivals, and events.

Navigating Chicago is easy. Block numbers are consistent across the whole city. Standard blocks, of 100 addresses each, are roughly 1/8th of a mile long. (Hence, a mile is equivalent to a street number difference of 800.) Each street is assigned a number based on its distance from the zero point of the address system, the intersection of State Street and Madison Street. A street with a W (west) or E (east) number runs east-west, while a street with a N (north) or S (south) number runs north-south. A street's number is usually written on street signs at intersections, below the street name. Major thoroughfares are at each mile (multiples of 800) and secondary arteries at the half-mile marks. Thus, Western Ave at 2400 W (3 miles west of State Street) is a north-south major thoroughfare, while Montrose Ave at 4400 N is an east-west secondary artery.

In general, "avenues" run north-south and "streets" run east-west, but there are numerous exceptions. (e.g., 48th Street may then be followed by 48th Place). In conversation, however, Chicagoans rarely distinguish between streets, avenues, boulevards, etc.

Several streets follow diagonal or meandering paths through the city such as Clark St, Broadway, Milwaukee Ave, Archer Ave, Vincennes Ave, and South Chicago Ave to name a few.

title: Welcome to San Francisco
subtitle: San Francisco is a major city in California, the centerpiece of the Bay Area, well-known for its liberal community, hilly terrain, Victorian architecture, scenic beauty, summer fog, and great ethnic and cultural diversity. These are only a few of the aspects of the city that make San Francisco one of the most visited cities in the world.
descr:
San Francisco is located on a small seven-by-seven mile (11x11km) square of land at the tip of a peninsula between the San Francisco Bay and the Pacific coast. It has a population of 815,000, but is the center of a metropolitan area of 7.1 million. San Francisco is just one of the cities which makes up the entire San Francisco Bay Area. San Francisco's neighbors - municipalities to the east of the Bay Bridge, north of the Golden Gate Bridge, and south of the city are all part of separate counties, each with their own governments and local public transportation.

Walking can be an enticing option to get from one neighborhood to another, so long as you are aware of where you are and keep your street smarts. San Francisco is a city of friendly neighborhoods, but it is also a big city so be aware of your surroundings and keep in mind the dangers that commonly accompany a city of San Francisco's size.

Perhaps the most recognizable landmark in San Francisco and one of the most famous bridges in the world, the Golden Gate Bridge, spanning the Golden Gate, has been called one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World and is the first thing you see of San Francisco if driving in from the north, as it is one of the major road routes into and out of the city. Overlooking the Golden Gate is the Presidio, a former military post with beautiful architecture and a very scenic park setting. Within the Presidio is the gorgeous Palace of Fine Arts, built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition and reminiscent of Roman and Greek architecture.

The best way to find a good bar or club is to ask the advice of a local; but barring that a copy of The SF Bay Guardian or the SF Weekly will help you find something suited to your personal taste.
San Francisco is very much of a "scene" town, with a varying range of categorical experiences. If you want door-to-door bar hopping at friendly bars that serve PBR tall boys, definitely go to "Polk Gulch" in the Tenderloin and work your way up through bars such as Mayes, The Playground, and Hemlock.

title: How often should one travel?
subtitle: After i cross the border, any border, after the daily routine falls off and my habbits reduce to none, after my information intake reduces to actually talking to people, instead of staring at one screen (two, five screens) the whole day - some time after i leave e States, i feel tremendous freedom. And the effort to leave is worth it.
descr:
A friend of mine said once, like you travel and after a while you start tripping out. You dont need no drugs or nothing but your whole being, it seelf like you are on a fucking mushroom trip. It is a great feeling. From myself i would also add: yess all that, and more. When tripping without drugs, you have complete control and complete certainty that what s happening around you is actually real. The best "drug" available out there is not a dubstance, but a behavioral pattern. The best drug out there is the jet lag. The travel.
 
But eventually i come back and some days later, i feel this fear, like things are sinking back in the fog. The routine takes over, and you soon forget the joy uou felt, and similarly the effort you spent on getting out.
 
So how often should you travel?
 
I say, as often as you can. Getting out on a long weekend once a month is great. Travelig for a week once in 3 months is great. Basically the goal is to never sink back into the routine. Travel enough to always feel this "trip" that is the unusual behavioral pattern. And, you probably want to optimize the costs so, if living at home is the cheapest opion, you wantto travel just enough to be in the jet lag zone and not sink back into the routine. Ideally, you would think as your home as not home, you would think of anywhere you are as travel. So, how often shold you travel?
 
I say, let's start with once every three month, ad see where that takes us ;-)
