title: FTIM Portal :: Why Travel?
descr:
I thought I needed an excuse even, for traveling. Like, why do I go to this place or that? I don't know... And it is in fact exhausing, I see people get all sorts of mild deseases and fuckups when going to a completely different place. This one girl from Sweden, she says, she cannot wear contacts in America. Not that the client here is bad, it's just her body is not accustomed to it. Or this one guy from Canada, when he was in Brasil, he said, after 1 month he had like extreme joint pain, could not sleep because of the pain. Nothing wrong with his body, but traveling does get exhausting. So why bother?

Because! The best people! Are found in travel. And some of the best experiences. Surely it is inconvenient and expensive. But I can go to a hostel an in 5 days meet people who could be my best friends... if we were only in the same city for any length of time. That's how I am with all my best friends: they are all somewhere else, on other continents. Sometimes it makes me sad, but every time I experience this mode of travel, it makes me happy.

And it is not like the people are very different. Perhaps they are, but not by much. No it is the environment that makes them different. The mode of travel itself, makes them change their behavior. Tourists are nice. They are mesmerized by the beauty of things. I find internationals (tourists and students) my favorite kind of people. No prejudice, they accept most things as they are. Having experienced more than one culture, they are open-minded and see things that would evade a `local` eye. When I travel I trust people in a specific way (and mistrust some other people in another specific way). When I am settled, I do not have that clarity of judgement... and the people around me, those that are not immediately travelling, do not have the clarity of judgement either.

When traveling, you have to be quick. Sometimes you have only a day to make friends - although not I think that one day is really not enough, you need at least 3 days. But that is still very very little! A community that forms within 3 days is a strong community indeed. And there is so much happiness! When the behavior is light like that, it makes everybody happy. Settled life does not quite provide the happiness that I look forward to, when I travel.

So that's the reason. Exhausing, expensive, inconvenient? Sure. But the best people can be found there. The best people are made there. And after a while, it is just like pure happiness, the joy.

title: An old shop on a new street
descr:
As I am walking down the Hollywood Blvd in Los Angeles I see a lot of interesting stores all around. It is kind of peculiar, actually: the Hollywood Blvd itself is packed with people, but you go one block south and there is noone there. So, I am walking down and I hear this guy half-say haf-sing, "salvia, mushrooms..." I turn to him and say, you have mushrooms for sale really? He says, yes come into the store. And so I do, and browse their stuff. They have mushroom for sure, but I decide not to buy any, just whatever. The other goods they have are, sunglasses, watches, souveniers. I don't buy anything. Just when I walked out, it occurred to me that the gift shop is old! The couple running it is old, and the stuff they have there is also old, maybe good value, maybe not, but it looks not modern.
 
See, I woke up, walked out of the hostel, and the first thing I bought was sunglasses just across the street, and then I was like why not? And bought actually three pairs of sunglasses from that dealer. Yuip I lost one pair just yesterday, a girl came over and took them off my head, out it in hers and said, it is mine now. So I had to get another pair and if I lose/break them as the average rate of 1.5 per week, I may as well get more than one pair.
 
And at that old shop I bought nothing. The store next to it probably has hundreds or thousands of dollars in sales every day, and there are maybe dosens of people in it at any time. But the old store, I was the only guy browsing the items, and when I left, nobody was there.
 
Why am I saying all this? Because it occurred to me. Even if something has value, and you think you would lose value by losing that item - it may not be the case. I think the best thing that couple could do is get rid of their whole inventory and buy new, cheap, flashy, shitty stuff from scratch. Like the pairs of glasses that I bought (twice overpriced, as I found 1 hour later, but no matter). So, if you have a bunch of stuff that has some value - maybe, just throw it out. It weights down on you so, and without it you may regain the value relatively quickly, and what is more important, increase your capacity of gaining value, which is more important than the value itself. Do not be attached to old things. Just throw them out, or give them away to someone, and start from scratch, and feel happy, and be free. That is all ;-)

title: Experience with the Whalesharks
descr:
When I had my summer vacation, I came to experience a personal encounter with these gentle giants. They came in threes, fours, and even more. It was just recently in that town, where the whalesharks came to visit and because of a discovery of one fisherman, that they can be fed, so the townspeople and other fishermen decided to give small shrimps to these giants. Maybe these whalesharks have an information chanelling among them, because they got many all of a sudden and they come to visit the place every now and then. And  all of a sudden, because of the surprised visits of these giants, the town also became a tourist destination. 

Almost every month, people coming from the different parts of the Philippines and the world, flock to the town just to witness and have a personal encounter with these giants. Of course, these whalesharks have to be protected, so there are laws, rules and regulations on the whale shark watching in the town. Like you are not allowed to go very near to the whalesharks nor touch their skins. A watcher has to stay 5 meters away from the tail of these gentle giants and all other rules that protects it.

When I had my first encounter with the gentle giants, I was afraid and scared that I might be eaten by the whalesharks. It seems like when they open their big mouths, with me this small, it seems like they're going to eat me up. Waaaa. But one thing is for sure, they do not harm humans not like the hammerhead sharks and the white sharks which when provoked, harm others.

title: Philippines
descr:
I love to travel. I love visiting other places most especially going into historic and Spanish-old places. I love visiting museums and see the different artifacts that were collected during different eras and centuries. The Philippines, which was under the Spanish rule for more than 300 years have a rich source of historical stuffs. When you go visit the different provinces, the Philippines can offer you a lot of it. An archipelago, the different provinces of the Philippines also share different stories based on the artifacts and edifices that are being built in these places. Cebu is one of theses provinces which showcases different stories of its history.

When I went to the southern tip of Cebu, I passed on one of its municipalities, Boljoon. I was amazed on how the church surpassed the changes of time and how it was able to stand the changes of the weather. The geographic location of the church contributed to the ambiance of the place. The church stood there facing the sea. It was such a great marvel and a wonderful place to be.

When you visit the Philippines, do not forget to travel the different provinces and municipalities and discover Philippines' abundant history and culture. Enjoy!

title: Brasil: Fortaleza
descr:
Brazil is a destination of choice for many people, as one of the most desirable places to visit. However, most people never get to visit this beautiful country. It's a shame, because Brazil offers some of the most amazing places on earth and ends up being one of the dream trip for many people. You only need two things, to visit this country: take a vacation and some budget available, to visit all, and actually manage to get your deserved dream vacation! Fortaleza is a city in the state of Ceará in the north east of Brazil, this city is slowly becoming a tourist destination, favored by Europeans and Americans. People are attracted to Fortaleza throughout the year, because the temperatures there are perfect and the beaches are magnificent. Nightlife in Brazil is always known to be a unique experience, and Fortaleza is no different. In a stretch of three miles of beach called Beira Mar Avenue, you will find everything you might need to be able to enjoy to the fullest. You can have fun being on the street or in an outdoor cafe and still watching the endless parade of beautiful women walking on the streets.

Before the lights go out, one of the best thing is to enjoy the good weather that makes this region of Brazil great, and spend hours on the beach, sunbathing and enjoying what life has to offer, which is a good coconut water, sitting in the sun! If you have never drank coconut water, don’t leave Brazil, without experiencing this drink.

 

Enjoy, too, a good Brazilian barbecue, with rice, beans, manioc, many meats, caipirinha, you can’t miss!

 

The bustle and nightlife in Fortaleza

 

When the lights go out in Fortaleza, the party begins and it lasts seven days a week. From Monday to Sunday, nothing to this town! With festivities throughout the week where you will find many tourists and locals enjoying themselves together and if you are going to visit this city, you will be part of all these people enjoying themselves, laughing and dancing together to the sound of a good samba and forró!

 

Whatever your personal tastes are, in terms of night life in Fortaleza, you can always be sure to find what you want in terms of nightlife. But not only this field gives Fortaleza popularity. For'll find plenty of daytime activities to be able to do, will still find good hotels, great restaurants with very good food, drinks even better and always refreshing to deal with hot temperatures, but always very nice and also a very friendly people, always hoping for you.

 

Fortaleza is a big city with much to be able to do so, even if you're thinking visit this city, is better for you to stay more than 7 nights. Coming less then 7 nights, and you will not be able to visit everything in this city.

title: Round Trip To Australia In 2 Days (Or How I Got Deported From There)
descr:
Do you guys have any idea how far is Brazil from Australia. It’s like the other side of the world. The quickest trip goes thru the South Pole. No, I couldn’t seen any Coca-Cola polar bear from the plane. I think I saw an iceberg, but that was all.

About 4 months prepping for that. I’ve managed to pay about 1,000 dollars for it. It was a Qantas promotion, so I bought it in advance, last november. So the only thing missing is a Visa. No problem so far. I already have an american visa, I’ve have a canadian one, I’m well traveled in south america and even been to Europe. I have my own company (two, actually) that supports me financially so I can travel without worrying about money. All good. I even bought a lot of aussie dollars from an ex-staff member from LimeTime, also got some American Dollars and even Euros that guests from the hostel ask to exchange.

A girl friend of mine dates another friend of mine that is from Australia (Hello, Jason and Roberta) recently went there and she told me they ask for a Yellow Fever Vaccination card. No where in the visa form this is mentioned. But anyway. I have been to Peru twice, and they also ask the same. I got my shot about 5 years ago, but I just don’t remember where it was kept. So I decided to call the Australian Visa Central or whatever they call it, that ironically is located in CANADA, and I ask about it. They told me that yes, its a requirement, but if I didn’t have it with me, they would ask me to sign a form saying I was responsible if something happened, yadda, yadda, yadda… Well, fine then…

Whomever follows me on Twitter or Facebook knows all about my preparation. All my friends dying to see such a good friend leaving for such a long time (just a freaking month).

Well, guess what? One of my hobbies is DJing! Yes, I mix dance music on night clubs so people can dance and have a good time, and so do I. I don’t do it for the money, but only because I like doing it. I have no intention of becoming Calvin Harris and go around the world on tour. (Hope it happens, lol) But I wouldn’t skip the chance of DJing in some parties in Oz. After all, most of the tunes I play comes from there (Hello, Bag Raiders).

So, one of my former guests at LimeTime just so happen to work for Modular People, the label for Bag Raiders, Van She, Muscles, and so on… And when there was a Smirnoff Night Life Exchange party here, he put me in contact with Tim Poulton, that works with him and is the booking agent for those bands. We become friends and he was looking for some parties for me to DJ. Not only him as all my friends there, since I have plenty that I’ve met thru the hostel.

And since I have more than 1800 friends on Facebook and I dont know exactly where all of them are from, I decided to create and event and invite all my friends, and they had the option to confirm if they were in Oz so we could meet up. On the event I decided to write “If you know any party promoters, help me by getting gigs. Im bringing my DJ stuff, and looking forward to party with you all! :)” It took a while for anybody to confirm me on any gig, so I was already kinda hopeless. Some friends told me about other promoters, clubs, etc, when finally Tim sent me a message to confirm a gig. So we exhanged this messages on Facebook:

“Hey mate,

 First set I have for you is April 29th in Sydney, will that work for you?”

To which I replied:

“Sure… Im leaving Syd on may 4th, so ill be there. Whats the name of the place?”

Notice that at any moment we mentioned money. For the same reason I mentioned above. I didn’t wanna do this for the money. If by any chance they offered me anything, I would probably spend it all on booze at the same place. But that was never my intention. All I wanted to do was to mix some electro with some brazilian music that the crowd would like, get the aussie girls worked up, and luckily get out of there with someone! :P

Now the drama begins. The flight was alright, pretty long, but good. I decided to not take any of my equipment, not even my laptop I took with me. Only took my Hard Drive cause I was planning to buy the new Macbook Pro there. Tom (not Tim) has a BCD 3000, the same I used to use before, so that would be enough for me. Not even my big DJ headphones I took with me. Only my In Ears that I’ve been using lately (Kudos to Laidback Luke).

So, going thru immigration, obviously they asked for the Yellow Fever Card. First Mistake. But I already knew what was going to happen. Or I thought so. I’ve been sent to another person that asked me to wait there. He came back and asked if I had a cell phone with me, cause I couldn’t keep it with me while there. So I gave him my iPhone. Suddenly the same guy comes back and asks me what I do for a living. I told him I have my own hostel in Sao paulo. He insists. I insist on the same answer. So he asks me what I was doing in Australia. Vacation, I say. He insists again, and asks if there was nothing else I was meant to do there. I told him no. ANd he says My facebook and twitter says otherwise. Boom… That’s when I got in trouble.

@garfolino Just got my first gig in Sydney! :)

Just after Tim mentioned the party, I posted that on my Twitter. The problem is that for me GIG is just a party to play. Apparently GIG is slang for WORK!

So they print this out along with this other tweet:

@limetimehostels Bebeto is off to Australia tomorrow! If you’re there, join the event! Le Garfs Invades Australia!

There, now they are all freaked out.

So it starts a series of interviews and questioning about my intentions there. I told them I have no reason to be working there, that I have my own company that supports me very well financially, told them how much money I make, how much money I took with me (they counted it with me), showed them my credit cards, told them how many friends I have there, and all… I told them DJing is just a hobby, that I have no intention of making money out of that, I just wanted to have a good time with my friends.

Then it comes to the second biggest problem. They found Tim’s number on my iPhone and called him. He didn’t know what was going on, so he told them details about the party that even I wasn’t aware of. He confirmed the gig, told them the venue and when they asked him if I was getting paid, he says Well, yes, we pay DJs 50 dollars per hour. That’s when everything went to crap. But he even said he didn’t know how he was going to pay me for that since I dont have an ABN. (I dont know what ABN is, im just assuming…) So, I couldn’t receive that money. Ok, Its Australia, not Brazil, so everything must be done correctly.

I insisted that I have no idea he was planning to pay me for that. That I never talked to him about money. So they asked me for my Facebook password, which I promptly gave to them, but they couldn’t access it since when you try to log on facebook from a different part of the world, they ask for a lot of confirmations, so it doesn’t get hacked. If they needed my help for that, Id be more than happy to help.

So, no deal. They asked me to give a last statement telling them whey they should not cancel my visa and let me stay.

So I told them all again. I was there as a tourist, and just so happens I’m a DJ, that yes I wanted to DJ in some parties with my friends, just as a hobby and for fun, and I have no intention to make money out of that, because I really didn’t need to be travelling there. For me, it’s just like bringing a guitar and play at the beach, is that work? No deal. They cancelled my visa. Apparently, DJ is a profession indeed in Australia (it’s not in Brazil, yet) and to DJ at parties means work for them, even thou you’re not getting paid for it. I even promised them that if that was the case, I wouldnt do it. In my mind all I was thinking was that if they let me in, I wouldnt get anywhere close to a DJ booth. Again, no way, Jose. 

Well, the airport was about to close and the only flight back to Brazil was on the next morning. I’ve managed to get out of the airport, scorted, of course, to an Immigration Detention Center. I forgot to mention that I lost my jacket on the boarding gate in Buenos Aires. So for me not be cold, they even gave me another hoodie to keep. I was never treated badly by any of them. Only when they gave me frozen chicken, that I obviously didn’t eat, so I was hungry until the next morning when we went back to the airport.

So that’s me, Brazilian, DJ, Hostel owner, detained (not arrested), in the middle of a bunch of chinese people and people from other places that were obviously there trying to get illegal jobs, just waiting to be sent back to my country. Good thing is that I got my own room, so I just laid down and slept.

6 am they knock on my door and wake me up. I got release from that area, and they took me back to the airport. The whole time I was hoping somebody would come and say that it was all a huge misunderstanding and overrated, and would apologize and let me in. Silly me. I got locked up a bit more there, until they put me into my flight. But at least, they were nice enough to go to McDonalds for me and buy me some food. At that point I was starving.

Well, here I am, back in Brazil. And I’ve learned a few lessons. Set your Twitter account to PRIVATE. If it wasn’t for that, they wouldn’t know anything. And always take all your documents when travelling. If I had tried harder I possibly would have found my yellow fever card. I bet if I look for it now I can find in less than 30 minutes. And third. DJ is a profession in Australia. Always deny that you can mix music together.

On the good side I didn’t spend any money in Australia, so I bought a new Nintendo Wii with Mario Kart for the hostel at the Free Shop in Argentina.

title: Feel The Beat Of Jozi
descr:
The concept of Ubuntu is my link to all that I observe- this is the way individuals of all races, genders and culture are connected. Our social economic standards don’t matter. All you need to know is what a beautiful country we live in. If you get off your comfortable bottoms and come explore, you will feel and know what we live within and around. This exposure will provide no help to people who have lived here before. They know about the glorious weather, the big five and how the bush connects strangers. This one goes out to the people that think we ride to school on lions and have giraffes as pets. This stereotype will not do, so come and see what is really going on. We are a collective of new and old, and always inspired to be as real and raw as it gets. Come and see the way Johannesburg people live together, help create opportunities for one another and share their open hearts with whoever requests it. 

I live for the streets. They let me know what is happening. The street vendors are like hawkers, creating opportunities to sell at traffic lights wherever you travel. You could easily buy an entire box of fruit, a new pair of sunglasses and a car charger from the comfort of your own car. They present township art as a classic and will always be a souvenir to bring home. They capture what you experience. 

Jo’burg taught me to drive. Cape Town made me walk. I walk not knowing what will find me, and enjoy the lack of expectation every time it arrives. Each journey leaves me with an impact. This is not just a trip, but a destination. When you interact with the people here, they make you feel a part of this place.  The people living on the streets teach me something every time I venture out my house. They live for simplicity- bread, kindness, a form of shelter and conversation. So I urge you to come and visit and see who takes the time to share some words and ask how you are.

title: The most interesting thing about Fernando de Noronha
descr:
Fernando de Noronha is an archipelago in Brasil, near Natal (the airport of interest for visitors). It is beautiful, there are things there that do not exist elsewhere. The existence of the fragile ecosystem is made possible by the island's location: it is very far from the mainland, which fact few islands can boast of.

Your plane ticket from Natal to Fernando de Noronha is likely to going to be as expensive as from wherever you at to Natal. Yes, this is an expensive place to visit. Because it is so remote, the plane burns a lot of fuel. Because the place is not as popular as, say, Paris, the prices are way up.

Another interesting thing is that the Brazilian government sets the restriction on the number of tourists that can be on the islan (500 at a time I believe) in order to preserve its ecosystem.

The most interesting thing, however, is that this island used to be a prison. Again, because it is so remote... Kind of like Alcatraz, but much much more intense. So, they used to go to great lengths to put prisoners there, and now it is one of the top world tourist attractions, expensive, luxurious, exquisite, rare.

title: We stand tall because we are proud. This is Jo’burg.
descr:
The binary of wealth and warmth sets up this dual partnership throughout the townships, suburbs and city life. Johannesburg represents an entire population that conglomerates the past, present and future, constantly finding an innovation that works for the diverse communities that have settled on this land. This is the land where Huguenot housing placed important status on Dutch influences and Afrikaans roots. This is where the Khoisan (ethnic African hunter and gatherer types) collided with the Boere to battle against the origin of land and resources. Who does what belong to? Who came first? Over here, all that matters is the next step.

Welcome to Gauteng- the city of gold, companionship and worth, where our way of being is reversed and substituted with development, building and westernised fronts. Here a nation speaks 11 official languages, each one brought to life with their different customs. Traditionally, we share what we know. Unity in Johannesburg is subjected to the way we interpret our past. We no longer choose to divide and conquer, separation of race, class and ideals are scrapped. We stand tall because we are proud of what we have accomplished.

Sub-cultures stem off the streets while high-end corporate executive officers fund their understanding and vision. We all fight to earn a buck, whenever the possibility and opportunity presents itself. Johannesburg is South Africa’s Europe- fighting the fight to rank a first world status. Our entertainment and hospitality standards intertwine culture and consideration. Finding innovative spaces to explore and work with make our entertainment more like art. The city is full of new audiences always finding light within what the values represent-success and creativity. This rat race is not only about eagerly upping the cash flow, its politics stand well corrected by society and comedians worldwide who are wittingly amused for a podium to protest and perform on. There is never a dull moment. The city cannot sit still.

With a congestion of people scattered around office buildings, these markets, museums and theatres help complement the Jo’burg skyline, this urban brewing creates the collection of unusual, pronounced and different people. We are a people, a nation, a community of all sorts, and it shows in all we do. The arousal of this city is due to its depth. Never judge something evolving here until you have experienced it. Being the largest man-made forest

the world has ever conquered, Johannesburg increases the oxygen when office air becomes stale. This city is not mine, yours or theirs. It belongs to us- always welcome to foreigners and open to communities for contribution and stories. So come and explore. It will change your perspective on the world we live and interact in.

title: Freebies in DC
descr: To start off with, I decided to join some early-bird queues to watch the daily and weekly performances that had on offer. This particular Sunday had an event at Meridian Hill Park. The weather explored raindrops, but immediately cleared up the afternoon for a drumming circle. African nomads in a park, in Washington, on a Sunday, who would have thought? As I listened to the drum beats and watched individuals join in, I managed to find a stranger to dance in circles with. Boy- was I happy. I can’t remember the last time I was consumed by a drumming circle. I was even offered my own drum to join in the beat, and until early evening, I managed to keep my rhythm going. This was matched by another free performance of lyrical jazz duets and slam poetry positions at Stage the next evening. I didn’t mind going alone because I knew how responsive these Americans were, even though I doubted it at first. I even got up to recite my own words, clicks and shakes were welcome, the people were so supportive. In two days, I managed to feel the vibe of the city without its historical connotations. I plan to visit Rock Creek Park for a tour of the night sky tomorrow, and for the next day, I will check my list out. All I know is I am definitely looking forward to the next few days.

title: New York: Island Metropolis
descr: New York is one of the greatest places in the world to visit! It is truly the center of American culture. Some of the best television shows made in America are filmed in New York City! If you are a fan of “The Daily Show” or “Late Night with David Letterman” for example, think about waking up early and getting in line so you can be in the studio audience! If you're looking for a chic party experience in New York City, think about going to Dream Downtown and partying until dawn. The ground floor of the building is a dance club that has been known to bring in some DJs of incredible quality. One of the coolest things about Dream Downtown is that it is also a hotel. Consider this place to be your base of operations! The floor above the dance hall even has a fantastic restaurant with a celebrity chef! If you are a fan of rap and hip-hop music, I would suggest visiting S.O.B.'s. Despite the colloquially vulgar name, this night spot features some of the best young and up-and-coming rappers in the country. Some of the most popular rappers out today got their start here. If you want to soak in the urban culture for a night and experience some ridiculously talented lyricists (and your sensibilities aren't easily offended), S.O.B.'s is where I suggest you go. For a relaxing afternoon to escape the hustle and bustle that is apparent in the majority of town, visit Central Park and lie in the grass and have a picnic with a loved one. I still remember the first time I set foot in the park and took in the sight. It's an amazing thing to be is such a beautiful, green oasis completely surrounded by elegant high-rise buildings. It's easier than you think to book tickets for a fabulous Broadway show and experience classic American theater productions, such as the recently performed Waiting for Godot, featuring Nathan Lane and John Goodman. Perhaps you want to catch something new and Avant-Garde? There are a lot of off-Broadway productions that provide unique, quality productions at more reasonable prices. Who knows? Maybe you might catch the next big star performing in one of these smaller theaters! One of the most unique bars that you can visit in the city is Crown Victoria. This is one of the most famous outdoor bars in all of New York City. It's the perfect place to casually drink some beers or sip some martinis as the sun does down and the breeze begins to whip through the city streets. There are even fun amenities like table tennis and badminton courts. Who would have thought there was a bar where you could drink while playing badminton? They also have some fantastic food and drink specials which will help you keep a little change in your pocket as you explore the city. If you do have some money to burn and you have some expensive tastes, hit up Madison Avenue! There are blocks and blocks of stores on this street, many of which are flagship stores for some of the most elegant brands in the world! It might be worth it to splurge on a couple of accessories on Madison Avenue, just to say you've shopped where the most fashionable people in the world go to shop! You could spend a lifetime in New York city before you've discovered all the fun you can have here. I can't wait to go back!

title: Berlin rocks!
descr: If you're looking for a place to chill out during the week and have a few drinks, Fuchs und Elster is a great spot to consider. Even though it can get a little crowded, it's still a great place to hang out for some cheap drinks and some time to just talk to your friends and draw up your next plan to adventure through the city. Come the weekend though, the cellar of the bar becomes a pretty fun club to visit, featuring soul and funk music, and the party tends to last all night. If you want to be a part of the German soccer experience be sure to plan a day around football at Alte Försterei stadium, home of FC Union Berlin. Get in the mix and have a damn good time, but remember as a tourist to be sure to root for the home team; you don't want to get yourself into trouble with the Berlin's fervent fans. You are a guest! If you consider punk rock and indie music your thing, I highly recommend the Magnet Club. It gets some really entertaining punk and alternative acts from around the world in addition to being a thriving spot in Germany's indie and punk scene. The venue has two stages and even if there isn't a band rocking out there is sure to be a dance party rocking. Club Lido is another great place that focuses on rocking out. The primary types of music that play here are Rock and Electronica. Expect a crowded atmosphere with bright lights and blaring sound to take you out of yourself for an evening as you experience some amazing European and German acts perform intense yet ambient music for fantastic audiences. During off periods, it's also a great place to catch a football game with some gregarious fans. For an elite, world-class orchestral experience, go watch the Berlin Philharmonic perform. Even though there is so much great musical culture in the city, and the punk, rock, jazz, and electronica acts are top-notch, nothing really compares to sitting at the Philharmonie and watching some of the most talented human beings on earth perform their craft to an adoring audience. For casual drinks and dinner, be sure to visit one of Berlin's famous Beer Gardens. The oldest of these that is still in operation is the Prater Garten. If you are looking for a more casual yet refreshing atmosphere, this is the place for you. It offers beer and drinks from noon on and dinner later in the evening, and having a beer in the Beer Garden is one of the most relaxing experiences you can have in the city. There is so much to do in Berlin and this just represents the tip of the iceberg. Be sure to schedule a lot of time here, because there is no limit to the adventures you can have in this affluent international capital.

title: Prague in the Summertime
descr: Prague is one of the most satisfying places to visit in Central Europe. It really has everything to offer, especially if you are into any kind of nightlife. One of the most popular destinations when visiting Prague is making the tour to Pilsen to visit Pilsner Urquell brewery, home of the oldest Pilsner beer in the world. This brewery was established in the 13th century and is still in operation. The classic Pilsner Urquell that you've tried at your local bar is nothing in comparison to the home brew, and there is just no excuse not to go. There are also brewery tours in the city that take you to the many brewpubs across the city of Prague itself. It really is a beer-drinker's paradise. If you are into the club scene, one of the best spots to visit is Karlovy Lazne, which is a huge club that is located close to the Charles Bridge. When you step in and look around your mind will be absolutely blown by the size of this place. It's the biggest nightclub in the entire region and it is always packed from floor to ceiling, especially in the cool, crisp air of the Czech summers. If you're more into a relaxing bar experience that will really suck you in, visit the Cilibar. As opposed to the electric air of the Prague nightclubs, this bar, and ones like it offer a relaxed atmosphere with great drink prices and even better tasting martinis. It is easy to get lost in the haze of this amazing bar and leave much later than you were ever expecting. For a more laid back experience after nursing that Central European hangover, visit the awe-inspiring Prague Zoo. This is one of the oldest, maintained zoos in Europe and has been recently recognized by Forbes magazine as one of the greatest zoos on the planet. Tigers, lions, polar bears, and giraffes, among hundreds of other animals, roam their enclosures across the fascinatingly beautiful landscape. Prague has a lot more to offer than most people would think. It is an entertaining, vibrant city with rich history and a really jumping night life. I would recommend it to anyone wanting to visit the region, and once you're on the streets, it's friendly to any budget.

title: Camden Town, British Boondocks in London
descr: The market is cluttered with around 200 stalls pawning off second-hand stories, vintage is a core word used around here. All eyes are clued up on the best bargains on jewellery, furniture and clothing. Naturally, my clothes fetish increased while walking through the market imagining swimming in the capacity of thrift goods surrounding me. Even though the cold hisses and spits its rain, and the miserable cold and grey undertones to the scene, Camden breathes with creativity. On the outskirts, people-watchers stand by, with cameras and snacks in hand, and watch as every outrageous and expressive individual walks by. It’s as if London was born for outcasts to develop. Their style evolves as rapidly as their drinks are poured. Draughts during the week days are common. If you don’t have a skill and have come to live the London life, a bar will take you in instantly. There begins the weekly pay for entertainment. The youth are never stagnant or stuck, because transport is so available. The Tube and bus system are organised for people to get around when need be. This is greatly useful for people’s party ethics. While the transport is going on, and being attended by a large percent of their population, their asset is getting to and fro. Public transport is definitely a plus. Music has its own culture this part of Britain. Individuals flock to bars and clubs for concerts, tickets are yearned after. That is why barmaids and patrons work for their piece of tuppence per night shift, in order to purchase a ticket to their favourite gigs weekly. I jumped on that route when visiting. I managed to watch Crystal Castles and Santigold in the time I was there. It shook my world around knowing that music was so close to my surroundings. I definitely needed to visit London once a year. The reason I came to London was to visit a couple of friends who were living here. Yes, I came as a tourist, but in my own right, I felt part of the Brit crowd that live day in, and out in this city. I enjoyed every last bit of London town, the culture sucks you in and excites you, even when you run out of toilet paper at home.

title: Havana, Cuba
descr: I was a part of a tour group during my stay, and witnessed the heritage sites during the day. The Viñales Valley was found after the expansion of tobacco cultivation. I kept my nostrils flared trying to breathe in the smell of fresh tobacco, but the cliffs leading into the valley didn’t look as safe as I wanted them to be, so I chose stability instead. This site was known for military placements in the Cuban War of Independence, as well at the Cuban Revolution. Che Guevara came up a lot; his iconic stance has really been embraced by the world today. On one of the days out, I learnt that Havana was founded by Spanish colonists. The city was built in the Baroque and Neoclassical styles, which are seen through the city. Its beauty is embraced by all who live in it. At night, I needed my space. Early evening strolls had become a favourite of mine. When I stepped out of my lodgings, I never knew what would happen or who I would run into. I always found myself using the pathway to the sea known as the Malecón. It made me think of the old pirates capturing natives who hid behind barrels trying to steal food and woman from the ship’s docking days. What I would do to encounter a hostage situation with a Latin pirate off-shore. The Captain would take me to sail through the seven seas. He would eventually allow my liberty and let me join forces with his crew. Anyway, side thoughts aside, Havana captured me. I am definitely coming back to explore some more.

title: Buenos Aires, Argentinia
descr: My family are footy fanatics, so when given tickets to watch a game at their ‘la bombonera’ stadium, I had to accept. The fans, also known as ‘hinchas’ have a massive amount of enthusiasm for their soccer players. Being part of a community that puts all their energy into supporting their local sports team made me feel really good. My friend and I cooed at the boys, who are ridiculously handsome. I finally saw the appeal of a soccer player doing his thing on the field. Their swift athletic moves keep everyone interested. I have never been more amused to watch a ball be passed up and down the field. They are fierce. Watching a live match made me understand the hype Argentineans’ associated with soccer. I finally got it, and I had no judgement attached to it. I was glad I came to find the origin of this culture. It really captured the enigmatic qualities I had hoped I would find. Next visit, I plan to watch another game, it brought out a great energy in me.

title: Albuquerque
descr: Upon arrival in Albuquerque, visitors will quickly notice the Sandia Mountains that dominate the skyline. This is where the adventure truly begins for visitors. The Sandia Mountains feature towering mesas, deep canyons, and vast lakes. Hiking trails guide visitors along the mountain range and ski resorts are available throughout the winter season. Visitors may also tour the Sandia Mountains via the Sandia Peak Tramway. At 2.7 miles long, the tramway provides a unique and surreal view of the mountain range thousands of feet above the ground. Riders often rave about the experience of flying through clouds beside some of the state’s highest peaks. Ballooning is a popular activity in Albuquerque and one that is sure to offer visitors the thrill of a lifetime. The city’s mild, arid climate and unique natural landscape make it the ideal location for hot air balloon rides. Balloon tour guides can be found throughout the city and New Mexico. Balloon Fiesta, the world’s biggest festival for hot air balloon enthusiasts, is held annually during early autumn. Visitors will find some of the most affordable prices in the country for balloon rides in Albuquerque. After a day of enjoying outdoor adventures, Albuquerque offers visitors a unique flavor of city life. Fine restaurants reflect the city’s cultural blending by offering a number of dishes with historical and international influence. Spas and old west saloons offer adults a chance to relax and unwind, while the city’s zoos and theme parks bring families together. When the sun goes down, the fun continues with luxurious casinos featuring all-time favorite gambling competitions and clubs that offer the latest in style and music. Some of the biggest names in Albuquerque entertainment will even offer visitors a free ride from one of the many affordable hotels to their establishment. Albuquerque’s history spans even further back that the nation’s in which it resides. The Native Americans have called this region home for many years, and their influence can be seen and felt throughout the city. Ancient ruins remain throughout the surrounding area and mountains, providing a look into the life of ancient civilizations that resided here before. Many residents continue the traditions of their ancestors by providing visitors with pottery making classes, ancient celebration practices, and much more. The art and architecture featured throughout Albuquerque also reflects the rich history that helped build this sprawling city. And visitors may travel the historic Route 66 on the way to their favorite attractions.

title: A (Roma) adventure.
descr: I came back to reality when my food was placed on the table. My first bite was overwhelmingly good. My mood shifted from a lost to found state. I am so content in this moment. I am ready to savor the food in front of me as a companion. I wasn’t able to finish this rectangle delight of cheese and bread duo, so I downed the rest of my wine, paid my bill, and looked up for inspiration. The Torre dei Lamberti was calling my name. Now that my stomach was satisfied, I wanted my eyes to have the same feeling. I shoved my backpack behind me and started making my way to the top. I decided to save my Euros for food and brave the stairs. After a half hour, I reached the top. Wearing a proud smile on my face, I walked to the ledge to take in the dazzling view of Verona, and knew that taking this step was all I need.

title: Weak for Paris
descr: I was told tales of the rude inhabitants the French people conveyed. I prepped myself for the tone I would receive. I learnt French to counteract that. In the time I had started saving, I took up French audio lessons. I was adamant to have a conversation in their native language. The language barrier was no more, this entailed being part of their society, instead of repelling it. I visited the Louvre. I was completely taken aback by the Parisians commentary on the glass pyramid structure in front. They were never impressed with the modern context of it. After a five minute chat with a Parisian art collector, I acknowledged their arrogance in the culture and switched off my intellect for Paris. Instead of belonging, I opposed everything. It made those intoxicating nights wittier, having a collection of opinions. Debating became my favourite act to meander while there. En route to the infamous tourist attraction, I was amazed to find out that the Eiffel Tower was made entirely out of scrap metal, from start to finish. Startled by the height at first, we made our way to the top, which closed as we arrived, due to the weather conditions. We settled on the middle view, and by George, it was magnificent. This city could never be mundane. It glows. It’s alive, and it was all mine for a month to fall in love.

title: Dancing with Vancouver
descr: As soon as I arrived to Stanley Park, the trees caught my attention. With an approximate of 150 000 trees surrounding this piece of land, my lungs attached themselves to the abundance of oxygen that nature enhanced, and then fuelled up with fresh air. I lay down. While the clouds scattered the sky, the sun’s appearance was warm and majestic. The weather here made me feel whole and new. This sun was consuming me. Back home in London, sun was a moment of freedom. This moment felt like a generation of new life. After taking a lengthy stretch, I moved towards a path that I saw from the corner of my eye. Moving towards the Brockton Oval Cricket Pitch, I saw the eight Totem Poles gathered together. I moved in really close and stared them down. Spirits of ancient tribes were trapped in an animalistic character, and I was trapped in their stories. These monuments all have an individual connection to the land, all full of history and culture. I took my moleskin out and created my own narratives. I just happened to be in the park the same day as ‘Dance as Dusk’ was scheduled. I was thrown into an array of people leading me in lines and circles to traditional folk music. No partners were needed. Strangers made the effort to join in. I was thrilled, and lucky to have been there at the right time, right day. To this day, I still use my trusted point-and-find method.

title: Announcing the Winner of the Writing Contest 2011
descr: Congratulations to Ashutosh Ratnam, of postcardsfromparanoia.blogspot.com, who won 2011's Infinite Shelter writing contest! As the 1st prize winner, Ashutosh received $100 and kudos / recognition from us and our readers. Good job Ashutosh! Stay tuned for next writing and photo contest announcement! ;-)

title: Like two water drops are similar
descr: In the raging 90's I had a job on the side, fixing electronics for friends and friends of friends. Me being an engineer and knowing the craft, the side gigs allowed me to get by the decade of recession relatively easily (Translator's note: the Russian economy and politics of the 90's were crazy, that's why they are dubbed "raging 90's"). I mostly worked at this small village that was close to a big city, yet did not have any repairs / customer service for the electonics. This allowed me to pretty much own the market there. Although I had to walk 12km to get there, eventually I bought a bicycle and got to be quite efficient. I would take the train, then bike it 12km there. (Translator's note: commute in Russia is nowhere like commute in USA. A bicycle on the train is a rarity.) In this village I got to know this one dude really well, sometimes I would even sleep over at his house if I finished work late. He had grown-up kids: the older sister was a police capitain, and two younger brothers, twins, where just about to graduate from the local polytech college. (Google map http://bit.ly/z1GBHR). Them being twins, I could not for the life of me tell the difference between them, but they weren't upset. Eventually they also provided me some work, mostly referring their friends, for me to fix their boomboxes. (Translator's note: a boombox would in those days be perhaps the most advanced electronic device owned by anyone in a remove village.) Once the twins finished college their sister hooked them up with the police. In the raging 90's it was hard to get a job anywhere, so they were fortunate for their sister's connections. One went into OMON unit, another went into the homicide unit. (Translator's note: OMON is the police unit chiefly concerned with managing then-common protests, demonstrations, and other urban events.) A mere year later I could easily distinguish the twins. The guy in the OMON grew some muscle and became this characteristic strongman. The guy in the homicide unit, on the other hand, became bleak, sad and sick-looking. Their father complained to me: the first son gets to be on the open streets all the time, has everyone's respect in the village, even bought a car (then-rarity in Soviet Russia). The second son, however, has to deal with corpses every day, gets no perks and no recognition at all. And hence, two twins who were at first indistinguishable to me, became quite different due to the nature of their work.

title: A Face Crime
descr: Evening time, I'm riding the railcar home, listening to my iPad. I customarily put the volume very quiet so that I can hear what is going on around, but people around me perhaps assume that I cannot hear hem. Two women sit next to me and discuss my appearance, trying not to make it too obvious. They giggle as they discuss my jacket, hoodie and hat. I look out the window with my poker face on. Then one of them says to another: "look at his happy snout, he is probably coming back from a hooker!" At that moment I couldn't resist and looked her straight in the eye. The two women got embarrassed, stopped talking about me and stepped off the railcar shortly after. The funny thing is, I was actually coming back from my mistress to my family! So the two women, although did not know, were right. And now I am seriously considering what they say about the benefits of eating a lemon after the love joys.

title: Old mans secrets
descr: Â“As you may know, - he replied Â– young folks usually go to parties in evening. And guys always accompany girls home. Through central street, of course. If you walked together once Â– it means nothing. If twice Â– it is a kind of a reason. And if you were seen together for three times, you are unofficially recognized as fiancÃ©. So once I have accompanied a girl. We were talking when I had felt that she was getting her hand away. I was misunderstood. In a moment I saw that I was going directly into a puddle, but hadnÂ’t turned away. She had skirted the water and held my hand again. The next puddle was chosen specially. She had repeated her turn. The next day I went with another girl in the same way. And she behaved similarly, skirting the puddles. The situation repeated in a day. I went with the third girl talking to her and she held my hand strongly. I stepped into the water and she followed me, listening carefully. She hadnÂ’t mentioned the puddle. Then I went to another one which was deeper. No changes, she was still following me. We stay together since that time, living in peace and loveÂ”. Everybody stood with their mouths wide open. Those ones, who are older, asked granddad why he hadnÂ’t told about it earlier. So they may know how to choose a wife and be happier.

title: In time of war
descr: Year 1942, city Stalingrad (CCCP). Nazis are preparing an attack by tank echelon, with the intent to cut off the Soviet partisan forces from Volga (a river, a supply route). The only way to stop the Nazis is to blow to shits a warehouse, as found by the the Soviet reconnaissance, where the attackers kept tank fuel. The generals issue an order to destroy that warehouse. Colonel, commander of regiment RE-2, understands well why the order is issued to him: he has the only remaining dive-bombers on this frontier... but the dive bombers have not returned from the last mission. Yet the Colonel must comply with the order. The only flying machine under the colonel's command is a "??-2", a plane designed for transporting mail and antiquated by every measure. Its payload is 200kg at most, whereas the bomb necessary to blow up a military warehouse - fortified for the war - needs to be heavier. The Colonel orders the regiment'm mechanic: "Hang a `pyatisotka` on external locks." A pyatisotka weights half a ton. "The locks will break... The plane won't get off the ground." - Colonel's comrades express their opinions. "This is an order." "And who will fly it?" - they ask him. They well understand that this is a suicide mission. "Bring me a headset and a parachute," he answers. "You cannot fly, Colonel." - the mechanic tries to talk him out of it. "No, to fuck with the parachute, its just extra weight. Just bring me some vodka." * * * The plane, rumbling on the last breath, by miracle takes off and, not even trying to gain altitude, sets course for the enemy's lines. The plane due to overload is barely controllable, it cannot fly straight but rather tries to swirf sideways, it near turns upside down and loses balance. title: Things to do in Chicago
descr:
The city's lakefront allure and nightlife has attracted residents and tourists alike. Over one-third of the city population is concentrated in the lakefront neighborhoods (from Rogers Park in the north to South Shore in the south). The city has many upscale dining establishments as well as many ethnic restaurant districts. These include the Mexican villages, such as Pilsen on 18th street and La Villita on 26th street, the Puerto Rican enclave Paseo Boricua in the Humboldt Park neighborhood, "Greektown" on South Halsted, "Little Italy" on Taylor Street, just west of Halsted, "Chinatown" on the near South Side, Polish fare reigns at Belmont-Central, "Little Seoul" on and around Lawrence Avenue, a cluster of Vietnamese restaurants on Argyle Street and South Asian (Indian/Pakistani) on Devon Avenue.

Downtown is the center of Chicago's cultural, commercial and financial institutions, and home to Grant Park and many of the city's skyscapers. Many of the city's financial institutions (for example,, CBOT, Chicago Fed) are located within a section of downtown called "The Loop", which is an eight block by five block square of city streets that are encircled by elevated rail tracks. The name "The Loop" is sometimes also used to refer to the entire downtown area. The central area often is portrayed, as in the map at right, to include parts of Near North Side and Near South Side, as well as the Loop. These areas contribute famous skyscrapers, shopping, museums, a stadium for the Chicago Bears and convention facilities. Similarly, the area just west of the Loop and the Chicago River contributes to the commercial core.

The North Side contains Lincoln Park, a 1,200-acre (490 ha) park stretching for 5.5 mi (8.9 km) along the waterfront with the Lincoln Park Zoo and the Lincoln Park Conservatory. The River North neighborhood features the nation's largest concentration of contemporary art galleries outside of New York City. As a Polonia center, due to the city having a very large Polish population, Chicago celebrates every Labor Day weekend at the Taste of Polonia Festival in the Jefferson Park area.[48] The Chicago Cubs play in the North Side's Wrigleyville. Two North Side neighborhoods in particular, Lakeview and the Andersonville area of the Edgewater neighborhood, are home to many LGBT businesses and organizations. The area surrounding the North Side intersections of Halsted, Belmont, and Clark is a gay district known as "Boystown."

The South Side is home to the University of Chicago, and the Museum of Science and Industry. It also hosts one of the city's largest parades, the annual African American Bud Billiken Day parade. Burnham Park stretches along the waterfront of the South Side. Two of the city's largest parks are located here: Jackson Park, bordering the waterfront, hosted the World's Columbian Exposition in 1893 and is home of the aforementioned museum; slightly west sits Washington Park. U.S. automaker, Ford Motor Company, has an assembly plant located on the South Side. Also, most of the facilities of the Port of Chicago are here. The Chicago White Sox play at 35th Street.

The West Side holds the Garfield Park Conservatory, one of the largest collections of tropical plants of any US city. Prominent Latino cultural attractions found here include Humboldt Park's Institute of Puerto Rican Arts and Puerto Rican Day Parade, as well as the National Museum of Mexican Art and St. Adalbert's Church in Pilsen. The Near West Side holds the television production company of Oprah Winfrey's Harpo Studios and the University of Illinois at Chicago. The Chicago Bulls and Chicago Blackhawks call the West Side home at the United Center sports arena.

title: La Giudecca - Venetian Festival, Irish Interlude
descr:
The Fiesta- the Biennale: An old friend from Nagasaki invited me to Venice to cover the Biennale Architecture Exhibition, and to stay with her on the island of La Giudecca. Wonderful for a writer: both the theme (“People Meet in Architecture”) and the 2010 director of the Biennale, a Japanese woman architect, Kazuyo Sejima, appeared to signify a great break with tradition.  And it did—signify a break, I mean. It was wholly wonderful.

The setting:  La Giudecca is a small Venetian /island which now boasts international features: a new Hilton Hotel and NYC style graffiti, “ALL CITY CREW.”  But then La Giudecca has always had a fluid past. Its very name is a rumor, possibly a corruption of the Latin "Judaica" ("Judaean") or Jewish ghetto. 

It is a warm enveloping village. A chorus of “Ciaos!” broke out whenever we walked to the local bar (osteria).   Everyone on Giudecca seemed to know everyone else. Conversations were lively---about children, education, dogs, the high waters, and the terrible state of the economy.

Some Giudeccan women were much in vogue, elegant, etiolated (gladiator sandals, four-inch heels), swaying as if on the catwalk.  Others in housedresses, with missing teeth, gray hair worn in buns. Virtually everybody held a cell phone in one hand and a lit unfiltered Camel in the other. Offering a Camel was a regular part of the meeting and greeting ritual.  

Conversation in the osteria focused on children, tourism, and the waters.  Everyone commented on the aqua alta or high waters. Venetians constantly exchange intense accounts of the stages and effects of the moon on the waters, like San Franciscans talking about The Big One---edgy, joking, and nervous.

The osteria was delightful. But the social occasion of the week was my friend’s close Venetians friends' invitation to a party for their Irish visitors to the Biennale.  

Who were our hosts, these Venetians?  Artists, expats, former Bohemians many years resident in Venice, now landed gentry with children, land, palazzos. 

The evening was an almost exclusively Irish night.  No new Venetians need apply. And it was almost overwhelmingly stimulating. The themes of our evening’s conversation, to my ears, tended to be 1) the firm establishment of the evening’s pecking order by means of demonstrated economic success and 2) the ability to talk the hind leg off a donkey. .. Come to think of it, the second was a subset of the first. The talk was entertaining, often deadly.  A documentary that evening about a plague of bees at our host's country estate provided a handy metaphor for the evening.  watch out for sticky dangerous swarming stinging stuff!  

Robert our host was English, reserved, an eminent painter. In fact, a redoubtable woman academician, whose portrait he had painted, paid us a surprise visit that evening.  We all had to shift our places at the dining table to accommodate her and her husband. Some of us ended up clutching oily, sandy cold plates of clams on our laps far far away from the table, in Siberia.

Alison, Robert’s wife, an American, blonde, attractive, and charming, ran a gallery in Venice.  Alison starred in one of the evening’s documentaries, featuring the invasion of bees into her  Italian country house. The documentary film featured her family and friends as they attempted to cut out the combs from her house, trap the combs and the honey, and help lead the bees to a new locale.

And then there was my friend G., half Greek, half Italian, speaking six languages. Always accompanied by her little dog; enrobed in many layers of sweaters like an English country

woman; chain-smoker.  Whom I would always remember as valiantly battling a huge Nagasaki turkey. My kind host who had made the whole trip possible.

The guests were Irish folk in town for the Biennale—architects, writers, documentary film makers.  Highly articulate, funny, fond of slipping subtle insults into the chat.

These Irish were fluent, dramatic, ardent filibusterers.  These guys (and one very pleasant muted woman architect) may possibly have reserved some special zingers- for me—I had after all been billed as a female “journalist” by my helpful friend and hostess. Red rag to these bulls.

I did have one point in my favor-- the fact that I was Irish on my father’s side, no matter how many generations removed from the auld sod.  I did not tell them my mother was British.

I met three Irishmen in rapid succession- two filmmakers and one writer.  It was as though they had been lined up for my perusal.

The leader of the group was documentary filmmaker Dylan. Dylan’s opening lines to me about his own girlfriend certainly grabbed the attention.  He leered, “She’s like a bloke as a friend, but she cleans up nice, doesn’t she?”

There were some interesting tensions. After a two week holiday in Japan with girlfriend Dylan was now a self-proclaimed expert—on the country and on its women.   Despite the fact that there were two women in the audience who had actually lived in Japan and might correct him,  Dylan explained to his audience that any contemporary Japanese woman could be described as one of three G’s- Gucci, Geisha, or Goth. 

However, Dylan’s Japanese documentary was beautiful.  The ryokans (country inns), brilliant autumn leaves; the temples and shrine festivals- it was deeply nostalgic. The man was gifted, no matter how difficult it was to acknowledge it.   I had tears in my eyes. 

Dylan’s next Italian documentary was about a plague of bees, at our host’s country Italian estates.  Images—the large dripping combs of honey; the swarms of bees circling menacingly and stinging our hostess vigorously. We saw the dead bees; we saw the blood where they had stung our hostess.  Finally, the giant combs of honey were drained and stored.

The second Irishman I met was even more intent than our hosts on displaying his holdings.  He carried photos not of family but of his stately home, his land, and his pigs (he had advised his wife to keep pigs to occupy her mind… (they are intelligent creatures).  Well. I had no pigs and no land. . So I kept mum.

We did establish one thing in common. I learned that my favorite Venice Biennale architecture show had generally been acknowledged as among the Biennale’s best: “Motet for 40 Voices”, based on the Renaissance choral music Spem in alium nunquam habui by Thomas Tallis. 

I commented that technically it was stunning. Every voice, miked alone, stood on its own speaker and pillar in a huge semi circle. One could listen to this voice, or stand in the middle and hear all forty voices at once.  I said, it must have been quite a trick to get the mikes positioned exactly so that the ambient noise would not interfere. 

My respondent was affronted.. This was his métier, not mine. Or did I call myself a documentary film producer?   I said, mildly, I sing.  It didn’t mollify him.

After a discussion about Obama (I liked him,  he didn’t) and about Sarah Palin, whom he purported to love,  and I didn’t, he abruptly went silent,  then turned on his heel to  go for a smoke. .

The third man, named “The Little Monk” in Gaelic, a Gaelic linguist and historian, was grimly determined to describe his holdings, and his books.    To his urgent questions as to what I was working on I replied, mendaciously, the Biennale. He became agitated.  “How much of the Biennale are you covering?” “Who’s your editor?” “What is your page count?” I had apparently gotten right under his skin. As he continued to squeeze me for information, the party broke up. .

Well.  It had been almost too stimulating. I learned I too could emulate these Irishmen and women- orate, opine, slip the deadly shiv into my speech, and generally hold my own.  But I would be happy to let a decent interval go by before another such opportunity.

Coda:  At the end of my week in Venice, we decided to go out for dinner. .The food was delicious (pasta with arugula) and I’d had my first taste of Prosecco. It was very hard to leave.

My friend’s little dog took charge of saying good-bye.  She ran round and round barking madly. She leapt up, licked the tears off my face. I broke away finally, grabbed my bag, and headed for the water taxi.

title: The wall in the clouds
descr:
I simply love the take-off. The plane stops at the beginning of the flight strip, I imagine instantly the multitude of buttons of different colours in the pilot's cabin, which makes you think of a Star Trek episode (I saw only 2 of them in my life and only by accident), only this ones you really have to know well.

The sudden high speed sticks you to your seat and then you start asking yourself when?...now?...now?...now? I never guessed. We always took off at the moment when I started to focus more on the speed, or sound, or the natural peacefullness of the passanger next to me, in this case a cheerful german.

I start smiling. Have no idea why. I like the sensation, I have to admit, but I do aknowledge that this is not the reason. Maybe I got contaminated from my neighbour, or (I'm tempted to lie to myself), he did from me.

We estrange rapidly and apparently surely from the ground. My neighbour is picking his nose, making small balls and throwing them on the floor, between me and him, like he intends to build a german wall between us from his apparently very distubring snots, since the spacial proximity of my flowerish shoes and (let me take a look) his mountain boots was not taken into consideration.

Anyway, the man reads...so I have forgiven him, my shoes never. I stare discreetly. He is reading "Voodoo History", my shoes become exponencially more interested.

Let's get back to the take-off. I never succeed at identifying my house, building, district, car, streets (which name I never remember, because I am just not interested). The houses become tiny, that's the moment when I realize why are the sky people so frightening - because they can see our smallness.

We reach the clouds. My german neighbour sleeps with his book in his hand, his cleaned nose is tempted second by second to invade the space of the historical art of voodoo. I ask myself, how come the book didn't fall yet? Maybe it's beceause of the coulds, they make it float.

We pass the clouds. The sun is appearing, enlightening exactly my window. I take it as a divine sign, "I'm a special person" I think and start smiling again. This time for a known reason. I am hot. My palms start to sweat, I wipe them off, not at all discreetly, over my balck pants...I guess we passed the discreet line at the foundation of the german wall.

You won't believe this, he woke up! He starts reading again. Mostly trying than succeeding. A sort of a preparation for a really heavy sleep. I bet he will fall, hopefully, on the book and not on my shoulder which still hurts from my monster backpack.

I detected a polar bear in one cloud. I bet he's happy. He is.

I dropped my book on the floor. Big mistake. My neighbour germanish manner smiled at me...oh, well, so the wall didn't reach the mouth level, yet.

I don't have a watch and on the plane I am not capable of aproximating time...I guess you could say that I spend my entire life in a plane if you knew me.

The clouds remind me of snow, the snow reminds me of cold, I better not look at them. Anyway they are too many to be counted up.

I'm hungry, I could eat anything, anything for free. I never understood why are the prices so high in the plane, to give you the impression that the food tastes better or because they want to prive you from your principles? I'm taking it too far, I'm sure the explanation is simple and stupid, but i can only reach it through complicated eliminations.

How much time is left? Should I ask my neighbour? I don't think so, I'm too afraid to wake him up from reading. I look fugitively around, too many people that are going bald on this plane. If we would crash successfully, we would die suffocated by hair or snots. I would pick the snots, I use to eat them as a child. Many do. Yet, the sensation of the hair in your mouth...I'm sure the chinese used it as a torture and many betrayed their countries from it.

The stewardess has incredibly white teeth, a mouth like that can convince you of anything.

My neighbour woke up and is insisting on building the wall. If we crash successfully, I'm never getting out of here.

It's an extremely dense fog outside (how strange "outside" sounds in here, it's always an approximated one). It's like we're in the water. How would a flying submarine look like, or a plane diving? The submarine sounds more plausible, but boring. Maybe if there would really be one, it would be fascinating.

I wonder: how peaceful plane constructors sleep at night? In my opinnion these are the only people that can't allow themselves to be lazy at work. They have to check a lot (I tried to find a number, but 10 is too small and one thousand is too big, I got lost in between, so I stick at "a lot") of times to make sure everything is perfect. Here perfection must exist. I bet it's really hard to be a wife of a plane constructor.

The sky is superb. Clouds of different shapes and sizes, at different hights, through a blue that makes you believe that you finally discovered the true blue colour. Throught the holes in upper clouds I see the inferior layer of clouds, which move to the opposite direction of the superior layer or the same direction as the plane; I wish there would be a supernatural explanation to it or some complicated physics explanation, but I presume it's just an optical illusion. I shouldn't look at them. Illusions don't last long and I don't want to be dissappointed. The imposibility of counting is enough for now.

I don't want clouds anymore, I want food and an extra leg room, but both of them cost ten times more here, in the clouds. The constructor of the wall, my neighbour, is smiling. What did he do in Romania, I wonder. Doesn't matter, I want to believe he's happy and he loves his wife (he has a wedding ring) and she loves him and I hope they don't have the same habbits.

The pilot is annoucing that we're about to land. In a beaten black and blue English he gives us some local ground information and wishes us a "Happy Christmas!". He sounds bored, I guess he's not very passionate about the landing.

I have butterflies in my stomach. My palms are sweaty again and it has nothing to do with landing. It's about the fact that I'm about to kiss...I missed so much the earthly stuff.

We're landing. I always guess the "Now!".

title: Tropic of Capricorn
descr:
A Survival Guide to Rio
for Gringos

Safety of your passport is the primary concern for you during the trip. It is the most important thing and the thing that you absolutely may not fuck up under any circumstance. Take good care of your password, because without it you are likely to face hell.

The biggest problem when arriving to another country is the inability to understand the natives. (It is arguable that the biggest problem is not this, but unemployment and/or lack of money to travel but this aspect of the lifestyle won't be covered in this body.)

The survival guide to a nomadic life here is applicable to all countries, all epochs and all varieties of personalities. However the pragmatic part of this will be centered on the culture of Brasil, specifically Rio de Janeiro.

What is this lifestyle? My lifestyle is not for sale, and I put more effort than just buying it, to obtain it. That is basically what I mean by "Lifestyle." It is something that preoccupies you regardless of money, regardless of success---it preoccupies you because you and it are inseparable. It is your lifestyle.

Upon arriving I did not know the language. Generally speaking, if you have the money there are only four things that you must absolutely be able to communicate; the minimal set of survival items.

  1. You have to be able to ask for, and understand directions.
  2. You have to be able to book into a hostel.
  3. You have to be able to order food.
  4. You have to be able to get a beer.

If you go to Rio knowing only how to say this, you will actually be alright. Your experience may suck, but at least you will not disappear. As you can see, these things are very few and you can probably learn them in a week. It is beneficial also to spend some time understanding and memorizing grammar + vocabulary, however it so happens that learning a language is significantly easier when you are submerged in it, than when you are outside of it. So, do not spend too much time or worry over learning another language while in the States, unless of course you study language and it is a part of your lifestyle.
